image.altText: A young girl lines up for a plate of food

props.synopsis: Students are more and more schools are getting free lunches, and teachers say it's benefiting not just their bellies.

title.children: 'They're actually eating vegetables': How free school lunches are helping

image.altText: Anti-cable car protesters erect a sign up a mountain.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian government says its proposed changes to planning laws will "prevent baseless objections" to developments from "well-funded activist groups and anti-everything organisations" — a move labelled by critics as "undemocratic".

title.children: Move to oust 'anti-everything' groups from planning process condemned

image.altText: Journalists come up with plan to stop job cuts at the Newcastle Herald and Illawarra Mercury.

props.synopsis: Australian Community Media, publisher of the Examiner and Advocate newspapers, plans to move all mastheads, to one print publication a week as it adapts a new publishing model.

title.children: Newspaper publisher ACM plans to cut all mastheads to one print edition per week

image.altText: An old beige coloured building with outside corridors going around it.

props.synopsis: Former asylum Willow Court joins locations such as a former concentration camp in Europe and an African slave house as one of 365 global "Sites of Conscience".

title.children: Troubled convict-era asylum finds global recognition among historic sites

image.altText: A person stands on the top of Mount Wellington wearing warm clothes.

props.synopsis: Tasmania is the "healthiest" place to live, according to a new study. But while the island's state government is keen to draw attention to the result, experts are cautioning against reading too much into it.

title.children: Australia's 'healthiest' place result needs a closer look, say experts

image.altText: A young woman is taking a selfie with her two young kids and her husband.

props.synopsis: Frankie Jane Green and her family have to "share an address" with friends to meet school enrolment requirements while they search for a permanent home.

title.children: Family living in caravan fakes home address to enrol child in school

image.altText: Teacher standing at the front of a classroom with students watching on.

props.synopsis: Tassie has been at or near the bottom of the class for decades when it comes to education results. Will anything change following a recent independent review? The ABC's families reporter Fiona Blackwood joins Airlie Ward.

title.children: Can Tasmania's education system get a better report card in 2025?

image.altText: A Tasmanian devil shows it's teeth under a tree, has white and black coat.

props.synopsis: Wildlife researchers say they have never come across a male Tasmanian devil with such markings.

title.children: 'Unique' Tassie devil trapped by mistake released into the wild

props.synopsis: Tasmania's Education Minister Jo Palmer speaks to Guy Stayner for Stateline about the release of an independent review into the state's education system.

title.children: Education minister hopes for NAPLAN gains amid 'laser focus' on literacy

image.altText: Josh Inglis, Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne.

props.synopsis: Steve Smith broke more records as the man once dubbed his protege, Marnus Labuschagne, edged closer to being dropped. Here are the quick hits from day two of the second Test in Galle.

title.children: Quick hits: Smith and Marnus's differing fortunes as Inglis faces wrath of quirky rule

image.altText: A chauffeur in a black suit opening the door of a black car.

props.synopsis: For years politicians have used their private travel paid for by the taxpayer in questionable ways — from chauffeuring pet pooches to a country home, to having petrol paid for while on holidays.

title.children: Chauffeuring dogs, paid petrol: Ministerial driver rules for state politicians

image.altText: A woman facing the ocean holding her arms out with no one else around

props.synopsis: What if being single wasn't a problem to be solved but a state of bliss? For some women, living without their "other half" is the key to being complete.

title.children: 'No situationships, no dating apps, no exes': The women going 'Boysober'

image.altText: Donald Trump looking up at the camera as he sits in the White House

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump likens his proposal to redevelop the Gaza Strip to a "real estate transaction" and prepares to sign more executive orders at the White House. Follow live

title.children: Trump likens Gaza redevelopment to 'real estate transaction'

image.altText: Palm trees stand in floodwaters.

props.synopsis: Already flood-ravaged communities are bracing for intense daily falls of up to 250mm and renewed river level rises from later today, with a severe weather warning still in place from Tully to Ayr.

title.children: North Queensland bracing for another onslaught of rain

image.altText: a graphic of a man being arrested with telegram logos flying across it

props.synopsis: In an Australian first, sanctions have been put on the online far-right extremist network Terrorgram. But if the US moves away from combating the problem under President Trump, could tackling emerging threats become harder?

title.children: No leaders, no uniforms but here's why Terrorgram is a global threat

image.altText: The Cook Islands Olympic team waves their flag on a boat in Paris

props.synopsis: Wellington is at odds with the Cook Islands over a looming new agreement with China and the former Pacific colony's plan to have its own passport.

title.children: Why has NZ 'bared its teeth' at its smaller, former Pacific colony?

image.altText: The graphic includes three polaroid photos of Eric Mercy with big groups of First Nations children

props.synopsis: A surfing legend is being remembered for his "big heart" after he took his own life in the late 90s. But in this community, his story isn't the only one. With the power of their connection and the ocean, his children are fighting to change that.

title.children: The tragic death of a surfing hero led a community to take action

image.altText: Beach in Gaza

props.synopsis: After 15 months of war, children can still remember Gaza's beach side. But now, it has transformed into a vast landscape of destruction. Palestinians returning to their homes recall the better times.

title.children: Children once played by the ocean. Now Gaza's beaches are a 'sad' place

image.altText: A "Pam the Bird" mural is seen on the side of an apartment building.

props.synopsis: It's the divisive artwork that has "blown people's minds away" and left others fuming. In court this week, police revealed the inner workings of the man allegedly behind "Pam the Bird".

title.children: The police mission to hunt down 'Pam the Bird'

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: Leo Puglisi fronting a 6 News bulletin when he was 12.

props.synopsis: For as long as Leo Puglisi can remember, news has been his passion. But running a news channel from his bedroom while finishing high school isn't easy.

title.children: Starting a news channel at 11, Leo Puglisi juggles school and breaking news

image.altText: People walk past a tram and a bus stopped on a busy road under a blue sky.

props.synopsis: Law and order and the cost of living are front of mind for voters heading to the polls in the seats of Prahran and Werribee today, posing a major test for the Victorian Labor government.

title.children: Crime, hip pocket the key issues as Victorians cast votes in by-election

image.altText: man signs paper at desk

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump signs an executive order imposing sanctions on the International Criminal Court (ICC) over its investigations of Israel, a close US ally.

title.children: Donald Trump sanctions ICC, ousts federal election commissioner

image.altText: A painting of Rachael Gunn breaking hung on a white gallery wall.

props.synopsis: If there was one notable figure who was going to be parodied in art at this year's Bald Archy, it was always going to be Raygun, whose infamous breakdancing performance at the Paris Olympic Games featured in five entrants' works.

title.children: From Raygun to Dutton, no-one is immune from the satire of the Bald Archy brush

image.altText: Better Man director Michael Gracey, subject Robbie Williams and star Jonno Davies at the 2025 AACTA awards.

props.synopsis: Michael Gracey's Robbie Williams biopic that swaps the star for a chimp has taken home the biggest film honour at this year's AACTA awards.

title.children: AACTA Awards 2025 winners list: Better Man, Boy Swallows Universe dominate awards

image.altText: Close up of actress Charlize Theron with short blonde hair

props.synopsis: There is an "unprecedented" level of filming activity across the Canberra region at the moment, with Hollywood stars Eric Bana, Charlize Theron and Taron Egerton all in town.

title.children: Charlize Theron in Canberra amid 'unprecedented' level of screen production activity

image.altText: Close up of wet, squishy, thick, brightly coloured paint on white background, butterfly shaped.

props.synopsis: Is CJ Hendry a sub-par artist, marketing genius or both? The self-confessed Brisbane "bogan" attracts big buyers, but the art world's not so sure about her — and she couldn't care less.

title.children: Self-confessed 'bogan's' art attracting buyers. The art world's not so sure

image.altText: People stand next to flowers and candles laid on the ground

props.synopsis: Sweden's government says it will seek to tighten gun laws in the wake of the country's deadliest mass shooting at an adult education centre where the attacker appeared to have used several of his own licensed rifles.

title.children: Sweden to tighten gun laws after deadliest mass shooting

image.altText: an empty bed and a blood pressure monitor in a hospital corridor

props.synopsis: Roughly one-third of the psychiatrists leaving the state's public health system have rejoined as visiting medical officers, a higher paid contracting role.

title.children: One-third of NSW's resigning psychiatrists rehired as contractors

image.altText: Alex de Minaur waves to the crowd with his left hand at the Rotterdam Open.

props.synopsis: Yet to drop a set in Rotterdam, world number eight Alex de Minaur moves a step closer to a potential clash with Carlos Alcaraz in the tournament decider.

title.children: De Minaur cruises through to Rotterdam Open semifinals

image.altText: An empty, brightly coloured trailer advertising bananas for $2.

props.synopsis: Banana prices look likely to stay low, even if supply is temporarily disrupted by flooding.

title.children: North Queensland bananas selling at a discount despite flooding

image.altText: Two RSL officials with what is believed to be a wartime diary.

props.synopsis: An Adelaide RSL is searching for the mystery owner of what is believed to be a World War I diary after it was left on its doorstep.

title.children: Search for origin of diary from WWI left on RSL's doorstep

image.altText: Man in a blue suit and tie carrying a backpack.

props.synopsis: Sentencing submissions are heard in the NSW Supreme Court for Kristian White, the former police officer responsible for the death of great-grandmother Clare Nowland.

title.children: Court hears family's pain as ex-cop who tasered 95yo returns for sentencing

image.altText: a woman's silhoutte in a window

props.synopsis: Authorities are inquiring after three Thai nationals say they feigned illness to avoid having their eggs harvested while being held captive in Georgia.

title.children: Investigation launched into human egg trafficking ring targeting Thai women

image.altText: a woman in a blue and teal shirt smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: Major Liz Daly's seven-day peacekeeping duty became a month of terror and trauma, and now sport and the Invictus Games is helping her overcome it.

title.children: Major Liz Daly's Invictus journey from peacekeeper to competitor
